step.context: \text{What is the correct way to break }\dfrac{x^3 + x +1}{x^2 - 1}\\ \text{into sum of partial fractions?}
step.reason: \underbrace{\text{Degree of }x^3 + x +1}_{3}\gt \underbrace{\text{degree of }x^2 -1}_{2}\\ \text{In particular, to get }x^3, \left(x^2 -1\right)\text{ must be }\\ \text{multiplied with something like }\left(Ax +B\right)\\ \implies \left(x^3 + x +1\right) = \left(Ax+B\right)\left(x^2 - 1\right) + \underbrace{Q \left(x\right)}_{degree \lt 2}

x^3 + x+1 = \left(Ax+B\right)\left(X^2 -1\right)+C \left(x+1\right)\\ \qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad+D \left(x-1\right)\\ \implies x^3 + x+1 = Ax^3+Bx^2+\left(C+D-A\right)x \\ \qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\quad+\left(C-B-D\right)\\ \text{On comparing coefficients and solving, we get}\\ A =1, B =0,C=\dfrac{3}{2} \text{ and }D = \dfrac{1}{2}
\text{Y and Z are of the form }\int \dfrac{dy}{y} = \log \left|y\right|+C\\ \text{X is of the form }\int y^n.dy =\dfrac{y^{n+1}}{n+1} +C
